title: How to study for exams in biology - Quora

response.answer_text: I do not know how to answer this question to be honest. How do you do well in other subjects? I am guessing you find hard to remember a lot of names and concepts that biology entails. I tutored a lot of kids and they very quickly forget the names but remember the mechanism somehow.  The way I used to do was study a lot.  Funnily, I did not figure out a short cut. To remember and fix it in my brain cells, I used to write it and practice it with diagrams. Unfortunately, we did not had youtube at that time to explain us concepts in animation way so i guess you can understand something that way. Plus it is much easier to remember when you finish one chapter and solve problems at the end of the chapter. The more problems you solve the more of the concept gets clearer in you head. Analytical thinking kicks in with memory playing its role, so it get fixed in your brain for good. Even scientists study hard in order to remember and do well in their experiments.  Making notes helped me. Reading aloud helped me. I guess you have to figure your own way what works the best for you. Good luck. thanks for AtoA.

Biology is definitely a science subject. First of all our concept should be clear. Secondly, you have to cram special terms like scientific names, labeling of diagrams etc. The best way to prepare for a biology test is you have to read your test topic at least three times than close your book and write in notebook whatever or how much you understand. After writing you have to check your work with the help of book and highlight your own mistakes through red pen or any sort of highlighter. Than again revise it from your notebook where you right. At the end, you have to revise lecture orally without book and record your voice or in the front of mirror. If you follow this way with the help of God, you definitely get good marks. Biology students’ should kept in mind that presentation or written expressions matters a lot. So, when you will attempt your biology test or paper you should emphasize on your written expression. For Example: The question is; Explain the organ human eye? Also draw and labeled diagram of eye? You attempt this question step by step like this; Definition of Eye.Definition of Lens.Parts of Eye.Structure of Human Eye.Function of Human Eye.Instruments used for studies of eye (optics).Diagram and Labelling of Eye.Than, definitely you would get full marks if you follow some good tips in bio paper/test...(Thank You) Regards: Momna Azmat.

Biology is one of the tough subject. Where understanding and memorizing both are important. You can use these things. Choose a topic then read it first to last one or two times.Take a blank piece of paper. Write here what you understand in which you just read.Pinpoint the area you don't understand and then go back to the materials and check it out.Review and read loud out in a complete sentences first to last.Apply NO 3 until you understand full concept and until you teach yourself first to last with complete sentences.Use analogy to remember tough word or keyword.Findout keywords which you don't know, learn, and understand first before going into details.Draw diagram beside each concept. which will help you to retain information long time.Test yourself before exam night. It will help you to find out in which area you don't know and which area your concept is unclear. And help you to retain information long time. Because when we write we need to think about the topic, realize the concept, and information we learn. It reinforce our memory to retain information more than before.Keep clam and relax. Take a Nap after studying. Research shows that short term information get into long term memory when we sleep after reading.Hope this helps.

Contrary to popular opinion, Biology is NOT mugging up. It's a very conceptual subject and if the basics are not clear no amount of cramming up is going to help you. What is the most fundamental part of Biology? Biochemistry. A perfect understanding of Biochemistry will allow you to understand most of the later stuff. And once you have understood you can not forget. Next is the General Cell Structure. A keen understanding will ease up your studies a lot. Lastly understand everything. Let's take the example of Plant Anatomy. There is no point in mugging up where what type of cell is but if you know the cell structure, biochemistry and have a general understanding of the role of various regions of plants, you can easily figure out what type cell should be located where. (Obviously root hair cells need something that can adsorb a lot of water so cells rich in lignin, suberin etc.) Always remember, logically connecting all components is the key to understanding.

First, you have to know what kind of questions will you have in the exam and which topic is covered. Then you should pick up a textbook and skim through the relevant parts to have a picture about what you have to learn. After that you can deepen your knowledge, step by step, always paying attention to the relationships between certain notions and trying to understand the underlying mechanisms. If you make sense of what you learn the memorization part will be much easier. When you already have a really good overall picture of the topic you should start paying attention to the smallest details which will hopefully fit into your knowledge. Also, try to ask yourself questions about the topic (and also solve quizzes if possible) and if you don't understand something only by using your textbook, don't hesitate to investigate further on the internet.

Learn your vocabulary! You can't understand the questions or write coherent answers if you can't speak the language. The best way is to make vocabulary cards at the beginning of each new unit or chapter. Start with a stack of note cards. Write one vocabulary word on one side then the definition on the other. Now begin studying them. Take a word at a time and without looking define it. Check your answer. If you are correct , place the card in the"know" pile. If not , it goes in the "try again" pile. Go through the " try again" pile until you know them all and they are in the "know " pile. This helps us separate what we know from what we need to work on . We won't waste time going over what we already know, but can use the time to study the unknown material.

Good luck with that. If you are trying to cram all of biology into one night of studying, then you are screwed. I wish I had better news to give, but that is simply the way things are. What I can recommend is to relate the things you are being tested on to larger biological concepts. For example, if you need to know about phototropism in plants, make sure that you not only understand what it is, but why it is necessary for the plant to maintain homeostasis. If you actively try and relate each example to the major concepts in biology, then you will learn the material on a deeper level, and it will stick with you longer. I hope this helps, and good luck!

The strategy is not to study for the exam; the strategy is to stay with or ahead of the material.  If you're cramming material a few days or a week before exam time, you're doing it wrong. Things you should do: 1) preread the lecture material2)take notes in class and know that usually time spent on a particular topic will be tested. 3) voice record the lecture4) rewrite the lecture, and take time to understand the concepts5) close your notebook and see if you can accurately rewrite each concept in the detail in which your professor explained it in lecture.  If you can do step 5) with accuracy, you'll receive an A come exam day.

Here is a very simple method that works for most of the exams: Sit at a table with your courses, relevant books (no internet), a pen, paper, and a bottle of water.Cut all possible distractions. Just do it. You can do regular breaks if it helps you, but no distraction. Just a pause.Read, then understand the content. When you understand something, it is easier to memorize. And more useful than just learning by heart.Focus on what you don’t know yet. It’s pointless re-reading again and again something you already know.Do some tests and past exams. Quickly skim through what you know. Don’t waste too much time on what you don’t know, as the point is exactly to make you see your weaknesses, and then focus on them.Repeat 1–5 every day, all the day, until your exam.

I personally believe that studying is a lot more easier when we follow the ‘chunking’ method. The scientifically proven theory of chunking is that people tend to remember things better when they learn related ideas in small chunk. The other great scientifically proven method for studying/IGCSE preparations can be Mnemonics, which is a learning technique that helps retain information in our memory. I learnt this great strategy via a private IGCSE Homeschooling platform which i came across while i was revising. They cover an entire IGCSE syllabus and have such interactive videos and quizzes which let’s us to test ourselves and prepare better for exams. They have experts who are available 24x7 to assist students with one-to-one online tutoring. Due to the whole pandemic, they are providing the contents for free and i am making the best use of it. I hope it helps. :)Oh also it’s 2020 and it’s high time that we learn how to study smart instead of mugging the contents.

Everyone is different in the way they learn so the trick is to find out what method works best for you. I would try lots of different ways and see which one you like. Most people seem to think that reading and taking notes is a good way and for some it works well. However, some find more active and interactive methods work for them. Card sorts, games, quizzes, challenging friends, use of technology like BBC Bite size and so on - all methods to revise… I am always a fan of social revision too - getting together with friends to work together. A final method that works for most is exam practise. Get hold of some past papers. Do them first as if it were a real exam - no notes or text books, timed (usually assume 1 minute per mark but it may vary depending on the exam) and in silence. Then use your notes and discuss with friends to see if you can write a better answer. Finally, mark it using the marks scheme. Your goal at the end of all that is to get no difference between the first answer and the final one… Ok you are unlikely to get there but the closer you get the higher marks you will get in the final test because you are literally doing the best you ever can under exam conditions. To be honest, learning how to answer exam questions is a far more useful skill than the knowledge you use to answer them… often it can mean you get marks when you don’t know anything about the question just by writing a reasonable guess.

Biology is not just memorization - it follows patterns that you should recognize. You should know and understand how all the organelles contribute to cell functions, and when you are more advanced in your knowledge, you should understand and piece together how particular cell functions are mediated by proteins.  Study hard, but when you see patterns, note them and you will begin to see how everything fits together.

I've actually found the best way… So when you wanna sleep put your book/note book/notes under your pillow and sleep.(in case for this to work you shouldn't know much about the subject you wanna study) go to sleep. Then during your sleep you'll learn it.(bec of osmosis movement) There you go the only effective way to study this**.

Hi there... Biology is an interesting subject as long as you see it with an artistic approach. Don't consider it just like another subject and avoid pretending to be focussed on the plain texts. Biology is more expressed diagrammatically than theoretically in plain text. Try to focus on the diagrams and relate your text with them. It's the best way to comprehend the basics of biology. Hope it will help.  Good luck.

Do the work. On day one of the course turn up to the lecture with notebook and take notes and ask questions. Continue this habit until the last day of the course. Read the text book, do any assigned work and essays, seek help if you are really stuck and hand them in on time. If your course includes tutorials, either group of individual, go to them. Ditto lab sessions. Read around the subject. You should have access to a library full of books on biology, read the ones that cover subjects that interest you. By the time exams come around you should be sufficiently steeped in biological knowledge that they should be a mere formality. A skim through the notes, some sample questions and you will be as ready as you ever will be. Do not leave it all to the last minute, this is the kiss of death.

In schools : rata maro For Competition : samjo mat rata maro and revise as much you can. After selection get knowledge as much You can, But selection First. In College : study little more in detail and try to understand yourself so you can remember for very Long time.

Review all material you want to focus in on the things you really don’t understand. Going over things you are already good at is pointless. Read the biology book for the exam and use it as a guide while you look over your lecture notes. Watch videos if you still don’t understand the material there are plenty of resources out there to help you for Biology. Also, make flash cards that’s very helpful that’s how I study for Ap Classes. Go to your teacher or professer if you still having trouble it’s always good to ask questions rather than be sorry on exam day.

The best way is " understanding the mechanism " , it's useless to know and remember tons of nouns without knowing what they re for. This way my big suggestion is to , while studying , looking at  pictures or videos on YouTube in order to know how that thing you re studying works.

I would recommend doing more revisions, such as answering questions in the textbook without looking the answers and keep motivating yourself by saying that you can do to yourself. I’ve said that in my math test when I feel like I can’t and its actually works! Side notes: Goodluck with your test!

Know the concept inside and out. Some of it may be memorization and some of it might be how to apply it. Look at your material and firstly understand it and know what it is and then think of how you can apply it to the real world. That way you have a true understanding.

Well biology is my favourite subject and here is how i study it for test or just on regular basis: Do to study table, sit in comfortable position, pick 5–6 colored pens along with colors and sketch pens(more colorful- better learning funda of mine), take sticky notes and start reading chapter. Do-not ever consider doing” ratta” in bio as it will be big disadvantage when you study with lot of syllabus. Try to visualize everything and relate it to daily life. At end dont underestimate flowchart and mnemonics(they are a lifeline). happy studying

Categorize the syllabus into parts… Systems,Structures, environmental portion, Genotype and phenotype part etc. Spend some time on each with help.of.drawing maps and charts. You should be having a grip on basic concepts that you can bravely use time and again to show your command of subject.

I have gray hair now, but as a graduate student, I would try and rewrite an outline of my notes from memory. I also had to reread the chapters multiple times until I was able to outline them. To keep sane, I would walk to school, about 2 miles each way, with a stack of note cards in my back pocket. On one side I wrote key concepts or terms, and on the other a written explanation or definition.
You study. A lot.

Everyone’s study methods differ, so try what best works for you. My sincere advice is that you study for better understanding rather than blindly cramming the whole book because it’s easy to forget everything stored.
Set mind read clearfully Take tea or coffee Rest 15 minutes Ask yourself What you read Then go again underline what you understand Then go to summary And answer the exercise questions
Home Use this website and go on biology and there's loads of pass papers on there for bio you can either write the questions down then answer them or print the pass paper off
If You are preparing for board Exams than follow NCERT and make short nots from thos books.And if You are preparing for medical entrance exams than read Truman Publication Biology books.
Just clear your concepts and read definitions. Proper functions of organs. And DIAGRAMS :')

I don't know what type of exam you are talking for. But for all the exams follow the NCERT books first line to line.
